item.content:
Hello there !

This is my first post on this blog, and I’d like to give some advices I learned while trying to learn CyberSecurity and Pentesting more specifically. This page is subject to a lot of changes. By writing these lines, I’m still a beginner but that doesn’t mean I can’t try to help you ! I’ve scattered the web a lot, searching for the best ressources out there to learn these skills that you may want to learn too if you’re here, reading a lot of reviews, asking questions to relevant persons, IRL and on the Internet. I’ll try to always give you links to discussions thread that speak about the mentionned ressource, so people that know better than myself (and there’s a lot) can help you too. I will try to put a section with general advices that can help to learn a lot of things by yourself, like CyberSec but in general everything related to self-taught. If you have questions or comment that can be useful, you can PM me on differents socials, I’d be happy to talk with you :)

Note : I will use the word “pentesting” for everything related to CyberSec skills, it’s juste more convenient, but a lot of those ressources can be useful for a big range of Computer Skills.

Summary

Explanation of Chapters
[0.0] Foreword
[0.1] Pre-Pre Requisites

Explanation of Chapters

0 -> The start of the start. Ressources and advices for people who barely know what a VM is, who don’t know how to use Linux, don’t have Basic Networking Knowledge and these kind of stuff. If you don’t understand a heck about what I’m talking about, then you should really start here.

[0.0] Foreword

Pentesting, CyberSec, Hacking, call it what you want, is Hard. I don’t want to discourage you, but let’s be honnest, it is. You would’nt call yourself a writer because you wrote 2 essays at school that gave you a great mark or if you just red a lot of books. To become a writer, you have to write. Well to become a Pentester, you have to pentest. If possible everyday depending of your schedule. You have to do as much hands-on as you can, when you learn something, see something new, try it immediatly, the information is fresh in your brain, and you don’t want it to go, so do it again and again and again and again, that’s one of the best advice for everything self-taught. Don’t get me wrong, it’s really important to read man pages, take courses (just don’t take so many that you will end up not going deep enough for each subject) but hands-on is what will make the knowledge stick in your head for ever.

[0.1] Pre Requisites

Here, I will list ressources that can help you build that strong Basic Knowledge about computers in general that you’re definitely gonna need. Pentesting is kind of requiring you to know a lot of skills related to Computer Science.

If you start from here, I just want to say that it’s going to be a looooong journey, so buckle up, get motivated, and don’t stop until you achieved your goal.

First of all is English, you’re gonna need it. If it’s not your foreign language, learn it as much as you can, it must become your new language, think in English, do everything computer-related in English, watch movies/shows/news in English, read books, use translators whenever you find a word you didn’t know about before, everything will help you.

[MORE SOON]
